title: Teachings on Marriage and Discipleship
shortSummary: Mark chapter 10 records Jesus’ teachings on marriage, divorce, and the kingdom of God, emphasizing the sacredness of marriage and the humility required to enter God's kingdom. It also includes the encounter with the rich young ruler, lessons on wealth and salvation, predictions of Jesus’ suffering, and the healing of blind Bartimaeus, highlighting faith and discipleship.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus in Judea near the Jordan River, shortly before His final journey to Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and Messiah who teaches on marriage, discipleship, and the kingdom of God, predicts His suffering, and heals the blind.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who question Jesus about the lawfulness of divorce, attempting to test Him.

keyCharacters.name: The Rich Young Ruler
keyCharacters.description: A man who approaches Jesus seeking eternal life but struggles with surrendering his wealth.

keyCharacters.name: James and John
keyCharacters.description: Sons of Zebedee and disciples who request positions of honor in Jesus’ glory, illustrating misunderstanding of true greatness.

keyCharacters.name: Bartimaeus
keyCharacters.description: A blind beggar healed by Jesus, demonstrating faith and the power of Jesus to restore.

outline.heading: Jesus Teaches on Divorce and Marriage
outline.description: Jesus addresses the Pharisees’ question on divorce, affirming God’s original design for marriage as a lifelong union and condemning divorce except for hardness of heart.

outline.heading: Jesus Welcomes Children and Teaches Humility
outline.description: Jesus rebukes His disciples for hindering children and teaches that receiving the kingdom of God requires childlike humility and trust.

outline.heading: The Rich Young Ruler and Teachings on Wealth
outline.description: A wealthy man seeks eternal life but is challenged to surrender his possessions; Jesus teaches the difficulty of riches in entering God’s kingdom and promises blessings for those who follow Him.

outline.heading: Jesus Predicts His Death and Teaches Servant Leadership
outline.description: On the way to Jerusalem, Jesus foretells His suffering and death; James and John request glory, prompting Jesus to teach that true greatness is found in humble service and sacrifice.

outline.heading: Healing of Blind Bartimaeus
outline.description: Jesus heals a blind beggar whose persistent faith leads to his restoration and discipleship, illustrating the power of faith to receive salvation.

application: Honor the sacredness of marriage by upholding God’s design for lifelong commitment and faithfulness.
Approach God’s kingdom with humility and childlike trust, recognizing our dependence on Him.
Evaluate attachments to material wealth and be willing to surrender all to follow Christ fully.
Embrace servant leadership by putting others before self, following Jesus’ example of sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the divine sanctity and permanence of marriage.

keyVerses.text: Verily I say unto you, Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, he shall not enter therein.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the necessity of humility and trust to enter God’s kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And Jesus looking upon them saith, With men it is impossible, but not with God: for with God all things are possible.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reassures believers that salvation and transformation are possible only through God’s power.

keyVerses.text: For even the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals Jesus’ mission of humble service and sacrificial love as the model for His followers.
